Shane_Stockton:
{{short description|American singer-songwriter}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Kelly Shane Brooks | image = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Kelly Shane Brooks | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1974|3|18}} | origin = [[Breckenridge, Texas]], United States | instrument = Vocals, guitar | genre = [[Country music|Country]] | occupation = Singer-songwriter | years_active = 1998 | label = [[Decca Records|Decca]] | associated_acts = }} '''Kelly Shane Brooks''' (born March 18, 1974), whose stage name was '''Shane Stockton''', is a former American [[country music]] singer. He released one album, ''[[Stories I Could Tell]]'', through [[Decca Records]] Nashville in 1998. ==Biography== Kelly Brooks was born in [[Breckenridge, Texas]], United States. Recording as Shane Stockton, Kelly released a single "What If I'm Right." In June 1998, Decca released his only album, ''Stories I Could Tell''. Kelly wrote every song on the album, with one being co-written. Kelly sang with [[Buck Owens]] in [[Bakersfield, California]], at Buck Owens' birthday party. "What If I'm Right" peaked at number 54 on the country music charts, and the album's second single, "Gonna Have to Fall", reached number 51.{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|date=2008|page=404|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}} One of his songs, "My Baby No Está Aquí No More", appeared on Garth Brooks's 2005 album ''The Lost Sessions''.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/r444968|title=''Highways & Dance Halls''|last=Dinoia|first=Maria Konicki|work=Allmusic|accessdate=September 20, 2011}} Kelly Brooks lost his recording contract in 1999 and has not recorded since.{{cite web|url=http://www.kcbd.com/story/866727/whatever-happened-to-country-musics-shane-stockton?redirected=true|title=Whatever Happened to Country Music's Shane Stockton?|date=July 22, 2002|work=NewsChannel Lubbock|accessdate=September 9, 2011}} In 2001, this time going as Shane Brooks, Kelly became the pastor at Elgin Avenue Baptist Church in [[Lubbock, Texas]], which later changed its name to Freedom Fellowship. Kelly remained there until 2010 when the church disbanded.{{cite web|url=http://lubbockonline.com/stories/050402/rel_0504020112.shtml|title=When God calls…|date=May 4, 2002|work=Avalanche-Journal|accessdate=September 9, 2011}} Kelly Brooks now resides in Granbury, Texas and pastors The Bridge Church of Granbury.[https://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_noss?url=search-alias%3Daps&field-keywords=Learning%20How%20to%20Overcome] {{dead link|date=February 2020}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! style="width:12em;"| Title ! style="width:20em;"| Album details |- ! scope="row"| ''[[Stories I Could Tell]]'' | * Release date: June 2, 1998 * Label: [[Decca Records]] * Format: CD, [[audio cassette|cassette]] |} ===Singles=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2"| Year ! rowspan="2" style="width:14em;"| Single ! colspan="2"| Peak chart
positions |- style="font-size:smaller;" ! width="45"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/shane-stockton|title=Chart results for Shane Stockton|magazine=Billboard|accessdate=February 19, 2018}} ! width="45"| [[RPM (magazine)|CAN Country]] |- | rowspan="2"| 1998 ! scope="row"| "What If I'm Right" | 54 | 86 |- ! scope="row"| "Gonna Have to Fall" | 51 | 92 |- | colspan="4" style="font-size:8pt"| "—" denotes releases that did not chart |- |} ===Music videos=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" !
